The preface to the VimalakÄ«rti NirdeÅ›a SÅ«tra states that it is the ultimate expression of the exhaustion of subtle transformations and the transcendence of wondrousness.

Its purport is profound and mysterious, beyond the comprehension of words and images. The Way surpasses the three emptinesses and is not discussed by the two vehicles. It transcends the realm of numbers and cuts off the realm of the mind of existence. It is vast and non-action, yet there is nothing it does not do. It is unknown why it is so, yet it can be so. This is the inconceivable.
Why is it so?

The sage's wisdom is without knowledge yet illuminates myriad things, the Dharma body is without form yet responds to all appearances, the ultimate melody is without words yet the profound scriptures spread far and wide, the hidden power is without plans yet its movements accord with events. Therefore, it can unify the myriad approaches, reveal things and accomplish tasks, benefiting the world without doing anything for itself. Yet the confused see the illuminating response and call it wisdom, observe the responding form and call it the body, encounter the profound scriptures and call it words, see the changes and call it power.
How can the ultimate of the Way be spoken of in terms of form, words, power, and wisdom, and discussed in terms of its spiritual realm?

Nevertheless, sentient beings have long been asleep, and without words they cannot be awakened. The Way is not self-propagating, its propagation depends on people. Therefore, the TathÄgata commanded MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« from a different land and summoned VimalakÄ«rti from another country. They gathered in VimalakÄ«rti's room and together propagated this Way.

The sutra clarifies that, in unifying myriad practices, skillful wisdom is the main principle; in establishing the foundation of virtue, the six perfections are the root; in rescuing the ignorant and deluded, compassion is the foremost; in speaking of the ultimate, non-duality is the gateway.
All these teachings are the basis of the inconceivable.

As for borrowing the seat from the Lamp King, inviting food from the fragrant land, receiving the great trichiliocosm with the hand, and the room containing the images of the universe, these are the traces of the inconceivable.
However, the profound gate is difficult to open, and the sage's response is not the same.

Without the basis, there would be no manifestation of traces; without the traces, there would be no revelation of the basis. Although the basis and traces are different, they are not separate in the inconceivable. Therefore, the attendant was ordered to name it.

The King of the Great Qin Dynasty, with his outstanding spirit surpassing the world and profound mind uniquely enlightened, propagated the supreme governance above the myriad affairs and elevated the Way's transformation below the thousand years. He always studied and enjoyed this canon, regarding it as the abode for the mind to dwell.
He lamented that what was produced by Zhi and Zhu was obstructed by the text, and was always afraid that the profound principles would be lost in the translator.
The operation of the Northern Heaven, the operation of communication, has its existence.

In the eighth year of Hongshi, in the year of Chunhuo, he ordered the Great General Changshan Gong, the Right General Ancheng Hou, and 1,200 monks who studied the meaning of the scriptures, to invite Master Kumarajiva to retranslate the correct text at a large temple in Chang'an.

Kumarajiva, with his lofty mind, contemplated the true realm. Having exhausted the center, he was also good at languages. At that time, he held the Sanskrit text in his hand and translated it himself. The monks and laypeople were pious, repeating each word three times. They refined and sought, focusing on the holy meaning. The text was concise yet effective, and the meaning was subtle yet clear. The subtle and distant words became evident here.

I, being ignorant and short-sighted, was in the listening group at that time. Although I thoughtlessly participated in the profound, I roughly understood the meaning of the text. I immediately followed what I heard and annotated it, briefly recording the completed words as a record without creation, hoping that gentlemen of the future, hearing it in a different world, would be the same.
Spoken by VimalakÄ«rti.
KumÄrajÄ«va says:
VimalakÄ«rti means Pure Name in Chinese, and was one of the five hundred youths.

He came from the Land of Wonderful Joy to visit this realm, and after his duties were completed, he was about to return to his homeland. He wanted to manifest his pure virtue and benefit sentient beings. Manifesting his traces and awakening the times must have a reason, so he ordered his companions to visit the Buddha but did not go himself.
Not going himself, it is known that he was ill.
How can this be known?
The five hundred companions all followed the great way, and in advancing virtue and cultivating goodness, they must always be together.
He ordered the one with the greatest karmic affinity for the Pure Land assembly, but they did not go together, clarifying that he had an illness.
Having an illness, there was an assembly to inquire about his illness.
The assembly at the sickbed is due to the gathering in the Pure Land, and the gathering in the Pure Land is due to the skillful means of VimalakÄ«rti.
Thus, the reason for the beginning and end of this sÅ«tra truly lies in this.

If one observes from one's own explanation, then the myriad sages have equal merit. If one seeks from the basis, then the merit is due to VimalakÄ«rti. Tracing its source, it is called Spoken by VimalakÄ«rti.
ZHAO says:
VimalakÄ«rti, in the Qin language, means Pure Name, a great being of the Dharma body.

His skillful path has no bounds, and his hidden and manifest traces are extraordinary. He manifests in this Saha world from the wonderful joy of the Pure Land. The reason for harmonizing with the dust and mundane world and using the path to teach the Dharma is that he always travels with Ratnasaá¹ƒbhava, as a companion in the Dharma city.

When the conditions for his teaching are completed, he is about to return to the wonderful joy. Therefore, he wishes to manifest his spiritual virtues and spread the TathÄgata's way of inconceivable liberation.

When his life was about to end, Baoji alone went to Shakyamuni, while he himself remained and manifested illness. This is why he initiated the topic of inquiring about illness and established the beginning of subtle words. The wonderful singing came from there, so it speaks of his teachings.
Zhu Daosheng said:
Vimalakirti means Pure Name.

He obscured his traces in the five desires and transcended them without defilement. His pure reputation spread far and wide, thus earning him this title. Those who value names and seek reality will certainly treasure his teachings.
The teachings manifest reality, and those who treasure them will eventually attain what they seek. From this, they come close to surpassing the words of the sages.
Sutra.
Zhaozhou said:
The sutra is eternal.

Although ancient and modern are different, the path of enlightenment does not change. The many deviant teachings cannot obstruct it, and the many sages cannot differ from it. Therefore, it is called eternal.
One name is Inconceivable Liberation.
Guá¹‡abhadra said:

It is also called samÄdhi, also called supernormal power, sometimes making long and short change their proportions, sometimes making large and small contain each other, transforming according to one's wishes, freely controlling phenomena, liberated without obstruction, thus called liberation.
The able one is able to do so, but things do not know the reason, thus called inconceivable.
It is also said that the great being of the Dharma body responds immediately to thoughts, not entering meditation and then being able to do so.
The mind attains mastery and is not bound by inability, thus called liberation.

If directly clarifying the emptiness of phenomena, it would contradict common practice and not be accepted, thus manifesting things changing according to the mind, clarifying that things have no fixed nature, things having no fixed nature then their nature is empty.
Bodhisattvas attain their indefiniteness, thus causing things to transform according to the mind, then the inconceivable is the clear proof of emptiness.
In order to manifest the principle, it is taken as the title of the sÅ«tra.
ZHAO says:
Subtle, distant, and profound, the two vehicles cannot fathom it, it is inconceivable.
Unrestrained and unobstructed, the dust and defilements cannot bind it, it is liberation.

This sÅ«tra begins with the Pure Land and ends with the Dharma offering. Although what is explained within is different, the inconceivable liberation is one. Therefore, it is collectively taken as the title.
Above, the sÅ«tra is named after the person. Here, the sÅ«tra is named after the Dharma.
Naming the sÅ«tra after the Dharma is to mark the ultimate purport;
Naming the sÅ«tra after the person is to use the person to propagate the Way.
Sheng said:
The title stainless may only refer to outward appearance, not necessarily the mind. Therefore, it further mentions its liberation, giving it another name.
The inconceivable has two kinds:
First, the principle of emptiness, which is not conceived by deluded thoughts;
Second, the marvelous and numinous, which cannot be measured by shallow knowledge.
If one understands the principle of emptiness, one will be liberated from the delusion of conceptualization.
Since the delusions have been removed, then what he does is difficult to fathom.
Now VimalakÄ«rti's movements and stillness are all wondrous and spiritual, he must have been freed from all delusions.
Being freed from delusions lies in realizing emptiness, expounding emptiness is what he realizes, thus the name VimalakÄ«rti has credibility.
If the name has credibility, then the seeking becomes more thorough.
When one reaches the seeker, how can one worry about not understanding?
Chapter on the Buddha's Land (1) Chapter 1: The Buddha's Land. KumÄrajÄ«va says:
The sutra begins and ends with the Pure Land, so the Buddha's Land is placed at the head of the chapters.
Thus have I heard.
Zhaozhou says:
Thus is a word of faith and obedience.
If one has faith, then the principles spoken will be in accord. If they are in accord, then the way of teacher and student is established.
The sutra is neither extensive nor concise, and it is not transmitted without faith, thus the words begin with Thus have I heard.
I have heard.
KumÄrajÄ«va says:
If one does not say heard, then it would be as if I myself had the Dharma.
I have my own principles, and my mind grasps at something. When the mind grasps at something, disputes and chaos will surely arise.
If I say I heard, then I have no principles, and therefore nothing to grasp at. Gain and loss, right and wrong, belong to what is heard.
Since I have no grasping, others have no disputes. Without grasping and without disputes, how can disputes arise?
It is also said that there are two kinds of love:
1. Love for the five desires;
2. Love for the Dharma.
Non-Buddhist renunciants can eliminate love for desires but not love for the Dharma, so their minds grasp at something.
The Buddha's disciples eliminate both kinds of love. Since love for the Dharma is exhausted, grasping and disputes completely cease.
The sÅ«tra begins by saying I heard, preserving this point.
Zhaozhou said:
The compilers of the sÅ«tras clarify that they personally received the holy teachings, without the errors of hearsay.
At one time.

The time when the sÅ«tra was spoken.

It refers to the place where the Buddha was.
Vi means a place suitable for growing rice.

The story of the jujube tree was mentioned in another sutra.

Zhaozhou said:
Bhikshu means either one who begs for pure food in Qin, or one who destroys afflictions, or one who upholds pure precepts, or one who can frighten Mara.
In India, one name encompasses these four meanings, but there is no single Qin word to translate it, so the meaning is retained in the name.
A different version says eight thousand great bhiká¹£us, KumÄrajÄ«va said:
They are the people who heard the sÅ«tra together.
It mentions the time, place, and people, using these three things to attest to what they heard.

It is the highest among all assemblies, revered by gods and humans, thus it is called great.
It can surpass the ninety-six kinds of debates, thus it is called superior.
Its number is eight thousand, thus it is called many.

It eliminates the five kinds of wrong livelihood to nourish the Dharma body, thus it is called one who begs for alms.
The reason bhiká¹£us and bodhisattvas are not counted together is because all bhiká¹£us have physical bodies, while most bodhisattvas have Dharma bodies, and their bodies are different.

For these two reasons, bhiká¹£us and bodhisattvas are not counted together.

Therefore, the arhats are mentioned first and the bodhisattvas later, because people think that the bodhisattvas have not yet exhausted all defilements and have not yet perfected their wisdom, while the arhats have already exhausted the three kinds of defilements and have accomplished wisdom. This is merely following human sentiment in determining the sequence.
There were thirty-two thousand bodhisattvas.
ZHAO says:
Bodhisattva, the correct pronunciation is bodhisattva.

Sattva means a being with a great mind.
One who has a great mind and enters the Buddha's path is called a bodhisattva.
There is no correct translation.
Another version says thirty-two thousand bodhisattvas attained great spiritual powers, and SHEN says:
There are generally three kinds of great beings: first, those who have left the household life; second, those who remain in the household life; and third, those who come from other realms.
Furthermore, there are two kinds: those with karmic bodies and those with the Dharma body.

Here, most of the bodhisattvas are Dharma-bodies, but their forms that respond to beings are the same as the traces of beings. Beings may be equal to what they see and give rise to inferior thoughts, so the great number is mentioned first, and then their virtues are listed.

The Sanskrit text says the basis of spiritual powers and wisdom has already been accomplished. The six pÄramitÄs and various dharmas are the causes of spiritual powers and wisdom, and the causes of spiritual powers and wisdom are the basis.

The Sanskrit text says much knowledge and recognition. Because their virtues manifest in a timely manner, all beings know and recognize them. Because all beings know and recognize them, many respect them. This meaning is clear.

ZHAO says:
Great wisdom is the wisdom of all kinds.
This wisdom takes the six perfections and the six supernormal powers as its basis. The great beings have already completed these fundamental practices.
It is established by the majestic spiritual power of the Buddhas.

Established by the majestic spiritual power of the Buddhas means being remembered by the Buddhas.
If one is remembered by the Buddhas, no one can obstruct or destroy it. It is like a fish that will surely succeed if it is remembered by its mother.
Zhizhe says:
The heavenly rain has no partiality, but it does not moisten withered trees;
Although the majestic power of the Buddha is universal, it does not establish those without roots.
Those who are established must have deep roots in the Way.
To uphold the true Dharma and protect the city of the Dharma.

The city of the Dharma refers to the Dharma of true suchness.
It causes beings to have no different views, so it is called protection.
Furthermore, all the scriptures and teachings are all called the city of the Dharma. It protects and spreads them, preventing them from being destroyed.
Those who are able to uphold the true Dharma also protect it by extension.
Zhizhe says:
Externally, it is a city that protects the Dharma, internally, it has the firmness of upholding it.
One is able to roar like a lion.
ZHAO says:
The lion's roar is a sound of fearlessness.
In all that is said, one is not afraid of the various heterodox teachings, like the lion's roar, with all the beasts submitting to it.
The lion's roar is said to be beautifully expounding the Dharma.
One's fame is heard in the ten directions.
SHI says:

The above speaks of those who know much and are widely learned, referring to those who manifest themselves in two directions and transform a pure country, with beings receiving their kindness and also knowing the people.
Now, speaking of fame being heard in the ten directions, it means that the way's wind blows far and wide, hearing their names.
ZHAO says:
Conduct fills the world, with praise being universally present.
Many people do not request friendship but are at ease with it.

There are two kinds of benefits, in this world and in the next. People interact with each other for the sake of benefit, so they invite and then act. The sages respond with compassion, so they go without being asked. Going means being intimate, and being intimate means providing protection, so it is said that without being asked as a friend, one can be at ease.

True friends do not wait to be asked, like a loving mother rushing to her infant.

ZHAO says:
Continuing the Buddha's lineage is the flourishing of the Three Jewels.

It is not just a matter of illuminating the Three Jewels and propagating the scriptures and Dharma, it means being able to accumulate goodness and build merit, and thus attain Buddhahood oneself.
Attaining Buddhahood means having the Dharma, and having the Dharma means having the Sangha. The merit of not being cut off lies in the future kalpas.
Now, speaking of not being cut off, it must be possible.

Moreover, in the meantime, I myself transform people, and after I transform people, people also transform beings, and beings and I both achieve realization, with the Three Jewels flourishing even more.
Since sentient beings are inexhaustible, the Three Jewels also do not cease.
Subduing the demons and enemies, controlling the various non-Buddhists.

Attaining the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, afflictions are permanently severed, thus subduing the demon of desire.

Without a body, there is no death, thus subduing the demon of death.

This is an example of that.

Demons refer to the four demons.
Non-Buddhists refer to the ninety-six kinds of paths.

There are three kinds of being free from the covering afflictions: First, when precepts are upheld purely, the covering afflictions do not arise;
Second, when the worldly path cuts them off, they are cut off but not yet exhausted, and when they do not arise, they are also called being free;
Here, attaining the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas is the complete elimination and freedom.
ZHAO says:
Coverings are the five hindrances.
Afflictions are the ten afflictions, and there are also innumerable afflictions.
When the three karmas of body, speech, and mind are all pure, then the coverings and afflictions cannot accumulate.
The mind always abides in unobstructed liberation.
SHI says:
The inconceivable liberation is of this kind.
Because there is no obstruction in matters, it is said to be unobstructed. Because it is unobstructed, it is liberation.
In one matter up to a hundred thousand, or in one country up to as many countries as there are grains of sand in the Ganges River, one penetrates and masters them without obstruction;
But one is still not able to be like the Buddha, with everything unobstructed.

This liberation is attained in the seventh abode.
Attaining this liberation, one penetrates all dharmas without obstruction, and thus the mind always abides in peace.
Mindfulness, concentration, dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, and eloquence are uninterrupted.
ZHAO says:
Mindfulness is right mindfulness.
Concentration is right concentration.
DhÄraá¹‡Ä« means to uphold goodness without losing it and to prevent evil from arising.
Not leaking or forgetting is called upholding.
There are two kinds of upholding: upholding that is associated with the mind and upholding that is not associated with the mind.

These four are the great being's essential uses, and thus they are always uninterrupted.
The separate version says their mindfulness is not distant and cut off, up to the accomplishment of eloquence. GUAN says:
Mindfulness is the mindfulness of the unsurpassed Way.
Uninterrupted means not being interrupted in the middle.
The meaning of uninterrupted pervades the following three dharmas.
Bodhisattvas who attain these four dharmas deeply enter and solidify them, not losing them in this lifetime but becoming even brighter through the kalpas, and thus it is said to be uninterrupted.
Generosity, morality, patience, diligence, meditation, wisdom, and skillful means, all are complete.

Above it says that the thought of the Way is uninterrupted. The thought of the Way is uninterrupted, and only then can one fully practice the six pÄramitÄs. When the six pÄramitÄs are complete, one's own affairs are finished. When one's own affairs are finished, one skillfully delivers others. The vastness of delivering others is no greater than spiritual powers. When spiritual powers are complete, one then transforms sentient beings.
In this way, the sequence is as explained in the chapter on purifying the buddha land later on.
Zhizhe says:
Complete refers to formless practice.
From the seventh ground onward, the mind and wisdom are quiescent and extinguished. Because the mind is unconditioned, there is no virtue that is not practiced.
Therefore, giving is ultimate in giving but has never been given. Precepts are ultimate in precepts but have never been observed.
The seven virtues have distinct merits but their characteristics are no different. This is called complete.

Wisdom is to penetrate the profound and subtle, and to have certainty in the characteristics of dharmas. To have knowledge without ignorance is called wisdom.

Although one may understand the characteristics of dharmas, one is able to not realize them. Abiding in existence without losing non-existence, and being in non-existence without abandoning existence, merging with emptiness and preserving virtue, saving both sides. Therefore it is called skillful means.

Since having consciousness, I have never seen the Dharma. Now I have finally attained it, and am able to believe and accept it, forbear it without fear, peacefully abide in it without moving. Therefore it is called forbearance.

Forbearance is the wisdom of non-arising.
Because it is able to endure the true characteristics, it is named forbearance.

Attaining this forbearance, one has no grasping or attaining of dharmas, and the characteristics of the mind are eternally extinguished. Therefore it is called the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas without attaining anything.

The way of non-arising has nothing to gain or lose, it is irreversible.
It flows and spreads universally, without being confined to one person, it is a wheel.
Since the Buddhas have turned this wheel, the great beings are also able to follow and turn it.

The Dharma wheel is the acceptance of non-arising.

Skilfully understanding the characteristics of dharmas and knowing the faculties of sentient beings.

There are no dharmas of different characteristics that he does not understand, and there are no different faculties of the multitude of beings that he does not know.
It is indeed the great assembly.

The Sanskrit text says the multitude cannot cover.
The multitude cannot cover it, clarifying that it surpasses.
Now, saying covering the multitude, the words are also the same.

Fear arises from insufficiency, but since there is no insufficiency, there is no fear.
Being able to speak but not able to practice is also a cause for fear, but now being able to speak and practice, there is no fear.
Being able to speak and practice is called the Dharma.

The ninety-six kinds of non-Buddhist paths each have their own followers, thus it says all.

The mind is adorned with the virtue of wisdom, and the body is embellished with excellent features. Adorning the mind is for the sake of advancing on the path, and embellishing the body is for the sake of captivating the world.

For those who revere the form, it is only to show the majestic appearance. How could worldly adornments be in the mind?

Fame can be lofty without being far-reaching, or far-reaching without being lofty.
Previously, it was heard in the ten directions, taking its far-reaching.
Now, surpassing Mount Sumeru, taking its loftiness.

Above the seventh stage, the faith of non-arising cannot be destroyed.

The light of the Dharma treasure illuminates everywhere, illuminating the darkness;

It is like the ocean having a divine jewel that can emit light to dispel darkness, and also because of the light it can rain sweet dew to moisten the withered and parched.
Among all sounds, his voice is the most subtle and supreme.

The various different sounds, he is good at their language and moreover surpasses them.
He deeply enters dependent origination and cuts off all wrong views, with neither existence nor non-existence remaining as habitual tendencies.
Zhaozhou said:
Deeply entering means his wisdom and understanding are profound.
Understanding that phenomena arise from conditions, then wrong views have no way to arise.

Here it clarifies the ability to expound the true Dharma.
The assembly all respectfully comply, just as the lion's roar intimidates the herd of beasts.

The flowing moisture of right wisdom is like the rain from heaven.

There are people who are wise but not eloquent, or eloquent but not wise. Since it says fearless and also rumbling, it clarifies that it is both eloquence and wisdom.
Zhaozhou said:
The distant rumbling of the Dharma sound awakens the sprouts, just like the spring thunder rousing the hundred grasses.
Immeasurable, already beyond measure.

Having attained the Dharma body and entered the realm of the unconditioned, the mind cannot be sought with wisdom, and the form cannot be grasped with an image, therefore it is said to be immeasurable.
Those below the sixth stage are called measurable.
Gathering the Dharma treasures like the ocean's guide.

Guiding sentient beings to enter the ocean of the Great Vehicle to collect the Dharma treasures, causing them to surely obtain them without difficulty.
It is like the ocean's skillful guide of merchants, who will surely obtain the night-shining pearl.

Zhaozhou said:
It is the truth of reality.
They are well-versed in the comings and goings of sentient beings, as well as the activities of their minds.

The comings and goings of the six destinies, and the good and evil activities of the mind, are all well-known.
Approaching the unequaled wisdom, powers, fearlessnesses, and eighteen distinctive qualities of the Buddha.

The wisdom of the Buddhas is unequaled, yet this Buddha is equal to it.
Furthermore, the Dharma of true characteristics is incomparable, only the Buddha is equal to it.

ZHAO says:
The Buddha's Way is transcendent and unequaled, only the Buddhas are equal to it, so it is said to be unequaled.
The reason for distinguishing its equality is to clarify the supreme great principle, which is as level as empty space. How could there be anything outside of it that can subdue it?
